SEARCH
Package org.loudouncodes.combinatorics

Class Derangements

java.lang.Object
org.loudouncodes.combinatorics.Derangements
All Implemented Interfaces:
Iterable<int[]>
public class Derangements extends Object implements Iterable<int[]>
Generates all derangements of {0,1,...,n-1} and exposes them via Java's enhanced for loop by implementing Iterable<int[]>. A derangement is a permutation with no fixed points, i.e., for every position i, p[i] != i.

What is a derangement?

A derangement of size n is a permutation of 0..n-1 such that no element stays in its original position. For example:

  • n = 3: derangements are [1,2,0] and [2,0,1] (but not [1,0,2] because p[2] = 2).
  • n = 1: none exist.
  • n = 0: by convention there is one (the empty permutation).

How many are there?

The number of derangements (the subfactorial) is usually written !n. It satisfies the recurrence: 


 !0 = 1
 !1 = 0
 !n = (n - 1) * ( !(n - 1) + !(n - 2) )

This value is available via size() and is close to n! / e.

Order of generation

Derangements are produced in lexicographic order over the full length- n arrays. The first emitted array is the lexicographically smallest derangement, and so on.

Algorithm (iterative backtracking; no recursion)

We build the permutation from left to right with a depth pointer depth (0..n). At each position depth, we try candidates v in ascending order, skipping those already used and skipping v == depth (to avoid fixed points). When we assign a value, we advance to the next depth and reset its candidate cursor; when we run out of candidates, we backtrack by one depth and try the next candidate there. When depth == n, we have a complete derangement to emit. This produces lexicographic order because we always try the smallest legal value first and only increase positions when necessary.

Why this is correct

  • No fixed points: We never allow p[i] == i during construction.
  • No duplicates: The search state is deterministic and each leaf is reached via a unique sequence of choices.
  • Exhaustive and ordered: Standard backtracking over candidates tried in ascending order yields all solutions in lexicographic order.

Complexity

  • Time: proportional to the number of derangements; the iterator does not enumerate non-derangements.
  • Space: O(n) for the current permutation, a used[] bitmap, and a small cursor stack.

Edge cases

  • n == 0: one empty permutation [] is emitted.
  • n == 1: no permutations are emitted.
  • Invalid inputs (negative) throw IllegalArgumentException.

Example


 Derangements d = new Derangements(4);
 System.out.println("Total: " + d.size()); // !4 = 9
 for (int[] p : d) {
     System.out.println(java.util.Arrays.toString(p));
 }

Implementation note: Each Iterator.next() returns a defensive copy so callers may mutate their own copy without affecting the iterator's internal state.

Since:
0.1.0

      public Derangements(int n)

      n - size of the permutation domain (must satisfy n >= 0)
      Throws:

  • Method Details

    • size

      public long size()
      Returns the total number of derangements !n using the standard recurrence: !0 = 1, !1 = 0, !n = (n-1)(!(n-1)+!(n-2)).

      Note: this uses long and will overflow for larger n. For classroom-scale n (e.g., n <= 20) it is typically fine. For arbitrary precision, provide a java.math.BigInteger variant.

      Returns:
      the subfactorial !n as a long

    • iterator

      public Iterator<int[]> iterator()
      Returns a fresh iterator that enumerates all derangements in lexicographic order.

      iterator over derangements of 0..n-1
